name: K2-69
scenarioDescription:
The K2-69 Exoplanetary System

K2-69 is a star with 0.55 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.49 times its radius. It is located 592.40 light years away from the solar system.

K2-69 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

K2-69 b

K2-69 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.07 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-69.

The mass of K2-69 b is 7.25 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-69 b is 2.32 that of Earth. At 7.25 Earth masses, K2-69 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-69, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by K2.
